image.altText: Headshot of a smiling Indigenous man in a patterned shirt

items.synopsis: While many say they are devastated by the No result in Saturday's referendum, First Nations leaders around the country are also hopeful that positive change can result.

title.children: Indigenous Australians look to the future with hope despite Voice  referendum defeat

image.altText: A man wearing a black shirt with a red and white slogan

items.synopsis: As the dust settles on the Voice referendum, WA state political reporter Keane Bourke explains how the west was lost, and what it means going forward for First Nations people.

title.children: WA was the final voice to say No. But the pathway ahead towards change is far from clear

image.altText: A close shot of Mundine's face, microphones just visible in the foreground.

items.synopsis: Prominent No campaigner Warren Mundine says a lot of Australians wanted to vote Yes, but the campaign failed them in two main areas. Follow what happens next with our live blog.

title.children: Mundine says there are two key reasons why the Yes campaign lost

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: 13YARN national program manager Majorie Anderson says the Indigenous hotline was fielding an increase in calls from people "disappointed" about the referendum result. Support for Indigenous Australians Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander crisis support line 13YARN on 13 92 76 eSafety Commission's First Nations resources "We're getting a lot of calls on the referendum at the moment," she told ABC Radio. "We did have to bring in some extra people. "And largely, the calls were about being disappointed about the outcome of the referendum." Listen to the full interview below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indigenous hotline fields increase in calls from 'disappointed' people

featuredLink.title: Indigenous hotline fields increase in calls after Voice result - ABC listen

children.content: 13YARN national program manager Majorie Anderson says the Indigenous hotline was fielding an increase in calls from people "disappointed" about the referendum result.
Support for Indigenous Australians
Aboriginal
Torres Strait Islander crisis support line

eSafety Commission's
First Nations resources
"We're getting a lot of calls on the referendum at the moment," she told ABC Radio.
"We did have to bring in some extra people.
"And largely, the calls were about being disappointed about the outcome of the referendum."
Listen to the full interview below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Associate Professor of politics at La Trobe University Bec Strating says global reaction to the No result is centred around Australia facing a challenge with reconciliation. "Some have said that it raises questions about how Australia can grapple with its colonial past. A number of pieces have drawn rather unflattering comparisons with other settler colonial states, particularly Canada." Dr Strating also says global news outlets have compared Australia's Voice referendum to Brexit. "There has also been comments that this is similar to the US presidential election in 2016 and Brexit referendum in 2016 in terms of misinformation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Global reaction to Voice referendum outcome

children.content: Associate Professor of politics at La Trobe University Bec Strating says global reaction to the No result is centred around Australia facing a challenge with reconciliation.

"Some have said that it raises questions about how Australia can grapple with its colonial past. A number of pieces have drawn rather unflattering comparisons with other settler colonial states, particularly Canada."
Dr Strating also says global news outlets have compared Australia's Voice referendum to Brexit.
"There has also been comments that this is similar to the US presidential election in 2016 and Brexit referendum in 2016 in terms of misinformation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We take responsibility as the prime minister did last night, for the referendum and we take responsibility for the outcome," Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said on ABC Insiders. "But I would say this. This referendum was the end step in a process which has been going on for a better part of a decade, in some respects longer. "I mean, it was the [John] Howard government which first talked about having recognition for Indigenous Australians in the constitution, and it was the [Tony] Abbott government who said that the way in which we should recognise Indigenous Australians is by asking Indigenous Australians how they want to be recognised in the constitution. "And that call really led to thousands of meetings which ultimately saw the meeting in 2017 at Uluru of Indigenous leaders which issued the Uluru Statement from the Heart and all we've done, in a sense is bring that to its final conclusion and taken that to the Australian people."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Richard Marles says government takes responsibility for referendum result

children.content: "We take responsibility as the prime minister did last night, for the referendum and we take responsibility for the outcome," Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said on ABC Insiders.
"But I would say this. This referendum was the end step in a process which has been going on for a better part of a decade, in some respects longer.

"I mean, it was the [John] Howard government which first talked about having recognition for Indigenous Australians in the constitution, and it was the [Tony] Abbott government who said that the way in which we should recognise Indigenous Australians is by asking Indigenous Australians how they want to be recognised in the constitution.

"And that call really led to thousands of meetings which ultimately saw the meeting in 2017 at Uluru of Indigenous leaders which issued the Uluru Statement from the Heart and all we've done, in a sense is bring that to its final conclusion and taken that to the Australian people."

image.altText: A map of Australia against a background of orange and purple stripes.

items.synopsis: Australia has voted No in the referendum, but the vote hasn't been uniform across states and cities. A small number of electorates, mainly in inner cities, are projected to have voted Yes.

title.children: A clear pattern has emerged in the way cities have voted in this referendum

title.children: What the places with the highest and lowest Yes vote can tell us about the Voice

image.altText: Albanese and Burney stand behind podiums in front of the Australian, Indigenous and Torres Strait flags

items.synopsis: For Indigenous Australians who supported a Voice to Parliament, this comprehensive loss is so much more than just a political loss, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The brutal truth of a referendum campaign that descended into a political inferno

image.altText: Trees in the foreground and waste facility in background

title.children: WA wine region town in uphill battle to stop growth of 'Mount Rubbishmore'

image.altText: young woman with nose piercings holding a baby wearing a white top.

items.synopsis: Unlike the other 20 or so cooing and crying babies attending a ceremony in Kalgoorlie, Sean is sound asleep — blissfully unaware he's being welcomed into a world that was not quite expecting him.

title.children: Sean's mum did not know she was expecting him until she went into labour. Now he's been welcomed to his community

image.altText: A cardboard sign on a tree, its "Vote Yes" label defaced with a red cross

items.synopsis: Labor and Liberal politicians attempt to pin blame for a damaging referendum campaign on each other, as some Yes campaigners fall silent to mourn the Voice's defeat.

title.children: Major parties heap blame for damaging Voice referendum campaign at each other's feet

image.altText: a surfer with his surfboard on the floor votes at a polling centre in  bondi for the indigenous voice to parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Support for Yes was strongest in the inner suburbs, while the majority of outer suburban, regional and rural voters said No. But analysts say the reasons why voters rejected the referendum question is more complex.

title.children: Voice result reveals more than just Australia's country-city divide

image.altText: David Littleproud stands over the hills in Maranoa.

items.synopsis: More than 3.6 million Queenslanders were enrolled to vote in the referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament — and with 68.5 per cent of ballots counted, just three of the state's 30 federal electorates supported the proposal.

title.children: You may not have heard of this electorate, but it just returned the strongest No vote in Australia

image.altText: Michael stands with his arms crossed in front of a colonial style building he has white wispy hair and mustache

image.altText: A woman wearing a backpack and carrying a baby walks through a crowd

items.synopsis: As the IDF prepares for "air, sea and land assaults" in Gaza, Iran's mission to the UN says the situation could "spiral out of control" if Israel doesn't stop the attacks. Follow live.

title.children: Iran warns Israel of 'far reaching' consequences over attacks on Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Pentagon has ordered a second aircraft carrier strike group to the eastern Mediterranean, near Israel. The USS Dwight D Eisenhower Carrier Strike Group (CSG) will depart from Norfolk in Virginia and includes a  guided-missile cruiser, three guided-missile destroyers, nine aircraft squadrons, and personnel. Secretary of Defense Lloyd J Austin said the shipment of more warships and aircraft was an effort to deter "hostile actions against Israel". The primary mission appears to be preventing Hezbollah, Iran or others from taking advantage of the situation in Israel and Gaza. "The increases to US force Posture signal the United States' ironclad commitment to Israel’s security and our resolve to deter any state or non-state actor seeking to escalate this war," Austin said in a statement. He is expected to arrive in Israel on Friday and meet with leaders to discuss what else the US can provide to the country.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pentagon says US is sending a second aircraft carrier to the region

children.content: The Pentagon has ordered a second aircraft carrier strike group to the eastern Mediterranean, near Israel.

The USS Dwight D Eisenhower Carrier Strike Group (CSG) will depart from Norfolk in Virginia and includes a  guided-missile cruiser, three guided-missile destroyers, nine aircraft squadrons, and personnel.
Secretary of Defense Lloyd J Austin said the shipment of more warships and aircraft was an effort to deter "hostile actions against Israel".
The primary mission appears to be preventing Hezbollah, Iran or others from taking advantage of the situation in Israel and Gaza.

"The increases to US force Posture signal the United States' ironclad commitment to Israel’s security and our resolve to deter any state or non-state actor seeking to escalate this war," Austin said in a statement.
He is expected to arrive in Israel on Friday and meet with leaders to discuss what else the US can provide to the country.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Syrian defence ministry says Israel has launched an air strike against the international airport in Aleppo, which has put it out of service. This is the statement it gave to Reuters: "The Israeli enemy carried out an air attack from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea, west of Latakia, targeting Aleppo International Airport, which led to material damage to the airport and it being out of service," the ministry said. This is not the first time the airport has been hit. Two days ago, Syria's state media reported Israeli forces had launched "simultaneous" missile strikes on two main airports in Aleppo and Damascus. The attack damaged both runways and put both hubs out of service. The strikes on the airports are intended to disrupt Iranian supply lines to Syria, a source told Reuters. The Israeli military has not commented on the strikes, but earlier said that two rockets had been launched from Syria toward Israeli territory that "fell in an open area". "No interceptors were activated according to protocol," the IDF said of that incident.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Syria says Israeli airstrikes have hit Aleppo international airport again

children.content: The Syrian defence ministry says Israel has launched an air strike against the international airport in Aleppo, which has put it out of service.
This is the statement it gave to Reuters:

"The Israeli enemy carried out an air attack from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea, west of Latakia, targeting Aleppo International Airport, which led to material damage to the airport and it being out of service," the ministry said.
This is not the first time the airport has been hit. Two days ago, Syria's state media reported Israeli forces had launched "simultaneous" missile strikes on two main airports in Aleppo and Damascus.
The attack damaged both runways and put both hubs out of service.
The strikes on the airports are intended to disrupt Iranian supply lines to Syria, a source told Reuters.
The Israeli military has not commented on the strikes, but earlier said that two rockets had been launched from Syria toward Israeli territory that "fell in an open area".
"No interceptors were activated according to protocol," the IDF said of that incident.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamas has announced three of its members from Lebanon have been killed after crossing the border from Lebanon into Israel and clashing with Israeli forces. The group said in a statement on Telegram that its militants had "inflicted losses" before being targeted by Israeli airstrikes. Since last Saturday's attack, there have been sporadic border clashes between Israeli forces and Hezbollah, a Lebanese militant group which is an ally of Hamas. These conflicts have also involved other armed groups in Lebanon including Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas says three members from Lebanon have been killed after crossing the border into Israel

children.content: Hamas has announced three of its members from Lebanon have been killed after crossing the border from Lebanon into Israel and clashing with Israeli forces.
The group said in a statement on Telegram that its militants had "inflicted losses" before being targeted by Israeli airstrikes.
Since last Saturday's attack, there have been sporadic border clashes between Israeli forces and Hezbollah, a Lebanese militant group which is an ally of Hamas.
These conflicts have also involved other armed groups in Lebanon including Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad.
AP

image.altText: Tim Tszyu and Brian Mendoza face off

items.synopsis: Tim Tszyu defends the full WBO super welterweight title for the first time against dangerous American Brian Mendoza on the Gold Coast. Follow all the build up and in-ring action in our live blog.

title.children: Tim Tszyu defends the WBO super welterweight world title on the Gold Coast

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Time for the women now, eight, two-minute rounds at super bantamweight for the vacant Australian title. Shanell Dargan (2-1-2), a Wiradjuri and Mununjali woman, may be familiar to some people more in tune with their pop culture references than I am. Dargan performed on X-Factor in 2014, telling SBS that she sung in front of John Legend in New York. Her opponent is Amber Amelia (3-1), a Palawa woman who hails from Lake Macquarie. This is the first time an Australian title will be contested between two Indigenous women, for a belt that now features the Indigenous flag on it. Both women came in under the weight limit yesterday (54.94kg and 54.74kg respectively) and, again, were fully respectful of each other during the face off which, frankly, was lovely to see.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shanell Dargan vs Amber Amelia

children.content: (Getty Images)
Time for the women now, eight, two-minute rounds at super bantamweight for the
vacant Australian title.
Shanell Dargan
(2-1-2), a Wiradjuri and Mununjali woman, may be familiar to some people more in tune with their pop culture references than I am.
Dargan performed on X-Factor in 2014, telling SBS that she sung in front of John Legend in New York.
Her opponent is
Amber Amelia
(3-1), a Palawa woman who hails from
Lake Macquarie.
This is the first time an Australian title will be contested between two Indigenous women, for a belt that now features the Indigenous flag on it.
Both women came in under the weight limit yesterday (54.94kg and 54.74kg respectively) and, again, were fully respectful of each other during the face off which, frankly, was lovely to see.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Long is livid and is walking around the ring looking for someone to argue with. But he was laid out on his back by the shot and then, when he did get up, was not steady on his feet. A decent stoppage and a win for Vousiutu, who bounces back from his defeat last time out. Look, that was not much of a spectacle. At the press conference on Friday Long said he was not sure why he was here. Given he barely threw a punch, neither are the crowd. He took the fight on barely a week's notice though and was not in great condition - he used his flamboyance to put on a show, but it was not too competitive.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Vousiutu beats Long by TKO

children.content: Long is livid and is walking around the ring looking for someone to argue with.
But he was laid out on his back by the shot and then, when he did get up, was not steady on his feet.
A decent stoppage and a win for Vousiutu, who bounces back from his defeat last time out.
(No Limit Boxing: Zain Mohammed)
Look, that was not much of a spectacle. At the press conference on Friday Long said he was not sure why he was here.
Given he barely threw a punch, neither are the crowd.
He took the fight on barely a week's notice though and was not in great condition - he used his flamboyance to put on a show, but it was not too competitive.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Now it's time for the biggest of big men, the heavyweights. Four rounds of action between Toese Vousiutu and the biggest boxer around, the 216cm tall Kiwi-American Julius Lloyd Long. Long (18-26-1) might not have the best record, but he has a monstrous reach of 229cm and weighed in at 132.2kg. He admitted that he came into this fight on short notice, but got plenty fired up at the face off at the weigh in, shouting in Vouiutu's face. Vousiutu (5-1) is looking to bounce back from defeat last time out and weighed in at 112.14kg.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Toese Vousiutu vs Julius Lloyd Long

children.content: (Getty Images)
Now it's time for the biggest of big men, the heavyweights. Four rounds of action between
Toese Vousiutu
and the biggest boxer around, the 216cm tall Kiwi-American
Julius Lloyd Long
Long (18-26-1) might not have the best record, but he has a monstrous reach of 229cm and weighed in at 132.2kg.
He admitted that he came into this fight on short notice, but got plenty fired up at the face off at the weigh in, shouting in Vouiutu's face.
Vousiutu (5-1) is looking to bounce back from defeat last time out and weighed in at 112.14kg.
(Getty Images)

items.synopsis: The Israel Defense Force's top spokesman says the killing of senior Hamas members is a "top priority". But analysts say tracking down these leaders will be complicated, and even if Israel is able to "eliminate" its targets, there is no guarantee it will bring an end to this war.

items.synopsis: New Zealand Labour took a step to the centre, and their supporters walked in the opposite directions.

image.altText: A young person expressing emotion.

items.synopsis: On a drizzly morning in March, thousands lined the streets of Adelaide to witness SA legislate a state-based First Nations Voice to Parliament. Seven months later, the outcome at a national level could scarcely have been more different.

image.altText: Paul Fuller's business's bank accounts were drained of $1.2 million by hackers.

items.synopsis: A hacker who stole $1.2 million from a family business already had confidential information before the theft occurred. Those in the field say cybercrime is rapidly evolving, and small businesses are facing increasing and targeted threats.

title.children: Paul's family business lost $1.2 million to a hacker. It's a sign cyber crime is evolving

image.altText: Two women, one blonde and one with red curly hair.

items.synopsis: In a digitally connected world, one in three Australians still report feeling lonely. From dinner parties with strangers to pledging to have a blind "friendship date" every week for a year, these women are finding creative solutions when it comes to making new friends as an adult.

title.children: Friendship blind dates and dinner with strangers: How to make friends as an adult

image.altText: a hand holds a magnifying glass with the picture of a bed bug up to a well made hotel room bed

image.altText: the skull of a deer with large antlers hangs on a shed wall

image.altText: Jimmy Thomson surrounded by flowers and foliage in his garden.

items.synopsis: When Jimmy Thomson's wife Roslyn died last year, he was distraught. Her love of native flowers was something he couldn't shake, so he continued her weekly tradition of making and donating native floral bouquets.

title.children: Together the Thomsons were a team. Now Jimmy is keeping he and his wife's floral bouquet tradition alive

image.altText: A mobile artillery unit firing.

items.synopsis: When Europeans colonised Tasmania they developed a hysterical fear of snakes but unwittingly provided them with the perfect food source, rabbits, which led to one venomous species growing into near 2-metre giants.

title.children: Bounties, gruesome treatments and the creation of giants: Welcome to Tasmania's violent past with snakes
